headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gourmet everyone, and welcome to The Hershey Company's First Quarter 2016 Results Conference Call. My name is Lindy, and I'll be your conference operator today. [Operator Instructions] This call is scheduled to be end -- to end at about 9:30 a.m. [Operato
componenttext: Gourmet everyone, and welcome to The Hershey Company's First Quarter 2016 Results Conference Call. My name is Lindy, and I'll be your conference operator today. [Operator Instructions] This call is scheduled to be end -- to end at about 9:30 a.m. [Operator Instructions] Please note this call may be recorded. Thank you. Mr. Mark Pogharian, you may begin your conference.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lindy. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to the Hershey Company's First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. J.P. Bilbrey, Chairman President and CEO; and Patricia Little, Senior Vice President and CFO, will provide you with a review of the
componenttext:
Thank you, Lindy. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to the Hershey Company's First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. J.P. Bilbrey, Chairman President and CEO; and Patricia Little, Senior Vice President and CFO, will provide you with a review of the results which will then be followed by a Q&A session. Let me remind everyone listening to today's conference call may be contain statements which are for lord looking. These statements are based on current expectations, which are subject to risks and uncertainty. Actual results may differ materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements because of factors such as those listed in this morning's press release and in our 10-K for 2015 filed with the SEC. If you have not seen the press release, a copies posted on our corporate website in the Investor Relations section. Included in the press release is a consolidated balance sheet and a summary of consolidated statements of income prepared in accordance with GAAP. Within the notes section on the press release, we have provided adjusted pro forma reconciliations of select income line items quantitatively reconciled to GAAP.
The company uses these non-GAAP measures as key metrics for evaluating performance internally. These non-GAAP measures are not intended to replace the presentation of financial results in accordance with GAAP. Rather, the company believes the presentation of earnings, excluding certain items, provides additional information to investors to facilitate the comparison of past and present operations. As a result, we will discuss first quarter results, excluding net pretax charges of $27.8 million or $0.04 per share diluted, which are primarily related to derivative mark-to-market losses and business realignment charges, both of these are defined in the appendix of this morning's earnings release, which is available on our website at www.hersheycopany.com. Our discussion of any future projections will also exclude the impact of these net charges.
And with out of the way, let me turn the call over to J.P. Bilbrey.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark. In North America, adjusting for the shorter Easter, we were pleased with our seasonal performance. However, nonseasonal candied mind and gum or CMG business was below expectation. The nonseasonal softness was more than offset by the timing o
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark. In North America, adjusting for the shorter Easter, we were pleased with our seasonal performance. However, nonseasonal candied mind and gum or CMG business was below expectation. The nonseasonal softness was more than offset by the timing of some merchandising and programming net sales that occurred in the first quarter that were initially expected to ship in the second quarter, netting to unplanned net sales delivery in North America.
Most of you are aware the soft retail takeaway performance across most of the CPG sector in the first quarter, especially in February. Easter timing in the current and year ago period makes it difficult to properly discern the current nonseasonal or every day candy trance. As a result, our full year net sales forecast reflects a tempering of nonseasonal everyday candy net sales growth.
As I'll discuss in a bit, North America CMG investments, including new products, advertising and increased levels of merchandising and display, accelerate in the second quarter and over the remainder of the year. Given the quality and level of these investments, there could be upside to our outlook.
In the first quarter, we are pleased with the gains we're making in Mexico and Brazil. As expected, China net sales declined in the first quarter. And more about this in a minute.
In January, I told you that we continue to look at our total cost structure. Building on that, today, we announced that we increased our annual savings target from continuous improvement and productivity programs from about $50 million to $70 million per year to about $100 million per year for the 3 years beginning in 2017.
Using a midpoint of the historical target, the incremental $120 million in savings results in a 3-year, $300 million initiative that should enable the company to continue to invest in its brands while also delivering on its earnings objectives.
We are off to a good start and expect that we'll exceed our initial 2016 productivity and savings target by $10 million to $15 million. Program savings will be generated from cost optimization across all segments of the business. Our focus on the cost structure enabled us to exceed our first quarter earnings expectations and deliver EPS growth versus the year-ago period.
This morning, we also announced that we're building on our better snacks portfolio expansion strategy with the purchase of the barkTHINS Snacking Chocolate line. Since its launch in 2013, Mark cents has quickly become a favorite snack brand due to its commitment to using simple ingredients, fair trade cocoa and non-GMO certification. BarkTHINS is a very attractive and uniquely crafted band that essentially created the chocolate thins category, a new form of chocolate snacking. We look forward to build barkTHINS by leveraging Hershey scale and retail. This acquisition builds on our snack strategy and complements our strong core confectionery portfolio, the heart of our company. And it adds strength and diversification to our offerings that allows Hershey to satisfy more consumer needs.
In the current environment, customers and consumers may seem increasingly focused on other snack categories, but the $25 billion CMG category is the largest segment of the $85 billion U.S. snack market. Customers and consumers, especially high-income consumers are increasingly looking for snacking alternatives. However, confection remains 1 of the top-selling snacking categories with household penetration of 94%.
So as you would expect, the majority of our time, effort and investments are focused on the CMG category. For example, we've done some extensive R&D and consumer market research over the last year that will result in a meaningful new product launch by year-end. And the barkTHINS acquisition will give us a chocolate snacking platform or, as we like to call it, snackfection to build upon. We are focused on our organic or innovation and growth as well as acquisition that meet the needs of the candy loyalists. CMG's variety seeking consumers who would like to try new things and consumers looking for better for new reassurance. 
Looking at U.S. marketplace performance, Nielsen retail takeaway for the 12 weeks ended March 26, 2016, benefits from an early Easter. Recall Easter was March 27 in 2016 and April 5 in 2015. As a result, CMG category growth was 8.7% for the 12 weeks ended March 26, 2016, within the xAOC plus C channels. Hershey's retail take away in the xAOC plus C universe increased 8.2%. Market share performance was in line with our expectations. Importantly, chocolate market share increased 0.10 point in Q1. However, this was offset by non-chocolate candy performance. As a reminder, the April Nielsen data will be impacted by the timing of Easter in the year-ago period.
Therefore, CMG and Hershey performance for the April year-to-date period will be less than Q1. Let me now build on my earlier comments and give you some details on our brand and in-store activity over the remainder of the year.
While we have already made investments, results have been solid. Specifically, Reese's market share is up 0.40 point in 2016, driven by new and refreshed television and digital marketing campaigns. Other brands that we're investing in include Kit Kat, where we launched a new Big Kat Kit Kat candy bar that is now available. And look for some interesting millennial-targeted created TV and digital campaigns using a Big Cat, literally storming the streets of New York. The Reese's Snack Mix and Hershey Snack Bites instant consumable items are off to a fast start with industry-leading innovation velocities. They are highly incremental to our base business and we're following it up with take-home canisters.
And we're also excited about some of the big in-store programming events such as our Classics promotion, our new team USA Summer Olympics sponsorship and Hershey's cross category in-store events, which leverages our new mega brand strategy. In the second half of the year, we'll also begin to communicate our simple ingredients message that will focus on Hershey bars and Kisses milk chocolate. And we also continued to gain share in gum with our category leading Ice Breakers brand. We've added additional capacity to meet demand, and we'll be supporting it with a new advertising campaign in Q2.
This is just a brief summary of the some of the strong activity we have in North America that will grow the business in the rest of the year.
Now for an update on our international business. Net sales were in line with our plan. Excluding China, where we knew sales would be down year-over-year as we lacked the slowdown that occurred after the 2015 Chinese New Year sell in, and the discontinued India oil business, constant currency net sales increased about 3.6%.
I was pleased with Mexico and Brazil, where constant currency first quarter net sales increased 4.2% and 9.6%, respectively. And in both markets, chocolate category growth was in the high single-digits.
In Mexico, we're optimizing mix to focus on global chocolate brands and building on our sigma relationship to accelerate coverage and share in the traditional trade. In Brazil, we're continuing to focus on the Hershey mega brand, milk chocolate tablet bars, cookies and cream and the wafer product. Constant currency net sales in India declined versus the year ago period due to the discontinuance of the edible oil business.
The media and vested brands, Jolly Rancher, -- and Hershey syrup where we are of our efforts and investments both all increase double digits. As we enter the second quarter, a new chapter for Hershey's in China begins as we merged the 2 teams into 1 united organization. Our initial plans impact some of our people and functions where there's some overlap. Savings here are not material at this point, but we're working towards balancing our business model in China versus our opportunities.
Importantly, in 2016, Golden Monkey got off to a good start with net sales below last year but in line with our plans and expectations. Most of these sales were made to quality distributors, who pay cash on delivery. We are executing against our plans to bring variety, news and excitement to the golden and munching monkey candy and snacks business. Confectionery innovation is focused on milk candies targeting young families, the better forming segment and Chinese classics, while protein-based snacks is concentrated on additional bean curd flavors and the introduction of a vegan and soy sausage. China chocolate category sales in Q1 declined about 10%, the low-end of our forecasted range. Given the slow start to the year, we adjusted our outlook for the year but still expect double-digit net sales growth in 2016, as we lap the trade funds that were necessary in the second and third quarters of 2015. Additionally, the remainder of the year, we'll be focused on establishing our new over brand message to reengage Hershey's and Kisses consumers.
This is tied into a fully integrated campaign, including TV advertising, digital communications and in-store merchandising that will bring the brands to live. While small, our e-commerce business in China continues to do well. In the first quarter, our e-commerce retail take away increased by 45% driven by Chinese New Year gifting sales. We continue to outpace the category and have a plus 10% share on the e-commerce chocolate market. Over the long term, we expect global economies and category trends to improve and that the investments in our international business to contribute about 1 point to our overall long-term sales target. 
Now to wrap up. From time to time, there are different confluences in the marketplace that can impact snacks and CMG growth. Hershey is always navigated and invested in its core CMG business throughout the cycles and has always ended up in a more solid position.
We are a consumer-centric, brand-building company focused on innovation and growth in every category where we participate, especially confectionery, and we want to satisfy the needs of our retail customers and new and existing consumers.
We take a long-term focus and continue to believe that investing in our business will benefit the company this year and well into the future.
I'll now turn it over to Patricia, who will provide you with details on our financial results.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, J.P. Good morning to everyone on the phone and on the webcast. First quarter net sales of $1.83 billion declined 5.6% versus last year, relatively in line with our forecast although partially due to the timing that J.P. referred to. Adjusted ea
componenttext:
Thank you, J.P. Good morning to everyone on the phone and on the webcast. First quarter net sales of $1.83 billion declined 5.6% versus last year, relatively in line with our forecast although partially due to the timing that J.P. referred to. Adjusted earnings per share diluted came in at $1.10, an increase of about 1% versus last year due to greater-than-expected productivity and cost savings versus our January estimate.
Excluding the negative impact from foreign currency exchange rates of 1.2 points, net sales declined 4.4% and was relatively in line with our forecast. Price realization on seasonal CMG products was more than offset by increased levels of resulting in a net price realization headwind of 50 basis points.
Volume was off [ph] 4.3 points due to a shorter Easter season and planned lower sales in China. Net acquisitions and divestitures were up 40 basis points benefit. By segment, first quarter North America net sales declined 4.3% versus last year due primarily to the shorter Easter season.
Excluding the 40 basis point impact of unfavorable foreign exchange rates in Canada, North America net sales decreased 3.9% versus the year-ago period. Volume was off 3.7 points and a list price increase on seasonal CMG products was more than offset by increased levels of direct trade resulting in a net price realization headwind of 70 basis points.
As we mentioned in January, the direct trade was primarily related to programs in the marketplace. However, the aforementioned softness of every day nonpromoted items resulted in greater-than-accepted unfavorable price mix. The combined Alan Katie and Krave acquisition as well as the model divestiture were 50 basis point benefit. 
Total International and Other segment net sales for the first quarter declined 15.4% versus last year. Foreign currency exchange rates were unfavorable by 7.3 points. The International and Other segment volume was off 8.4 points, due primarily to the net sales decline in China as selling related to Chinese New Year season was lower than last year.
International net price realization was a 1 point benefit and the impact of the model divestiture of 70 basis points headwind. 
Turning now to margins. Adjusted gross margin increased 20 basis points in the first quarter driven by greater-than-expected supply chain productivity and cost savings initiatives, partially offset by unfavorable sales mix and other supply chain costs.
On a net basis, commodity and packaging costs were slightly favorable. For the full year, we expect gross margin to be slightly down as greater productivity and cost savings and a slightly better environment at least for the time being is more than offset by installation and unfavorable sales mix given the update to our nonseasonal and instant consumable candy outlook in North America.
Operating profit in the first quarter was in line with a year ago period, resulting in operating profit margin of 21.5%, an increase of 120 basis points versus last year. The increase was driven by gross margin gains and lower SM&A, selling, marketing and administrative expenses. Total advertising and related consumer marketing expense declined about 10% versus the first quarter of 2015 due to timing. North America advertising and related consumer marketing expense is expected to increase over the remainder of 2016.
SM&A, excluding advertising and related consumer marketing, declined 9.3%, driven by the implementation of the business productivity program announced last June and the company's continued focus on efficiency and cost savings initiatives.
Now let me provide a brief update on our International and Other segment. I'm pleased there are total international business delivered on their Q1 plans. As J.P. stated, we're executing against our plans in the key markets of China, Mexico, Brazil and India and making good progress.
Adding to J.P.'s commentary on China, chocolate category contraction was greater than our estimate. Our updated forecast for the year reflects a return to growth, albeit at a lower level. In the broader economy doesn't improve, there could be further risks to our full year China chocolate and Golden Monkey sales forecast.
Distributor demand and net sales of Golden Monkey items have been consistent for the last 2 quarters driven by programs and products that are leveraging promotions associated with the lunar calendar year of the monkey. Given the increased level of in-store programming and innovation, we expect similar results over the next couple of quarters. Combined with a high leverage trade promotion that will be lapping, we're targeting Golden Monkey net sales to increase around 23% this year.
Moving down the corporate P&L, first quarter interest expense of $21 million increased $1.8 million versus last year. For the full year, we expect interest rate -- interest expense to be in the $90 million to $95 million range, greater than our previous estimate of $85 million to $90 million due to the use of commercial paper related to the barks acquisitions -- acquisition. The adjusted tax rate for the quarter was 35% and in line with last year. In 2016, we expect to purchase about the same amount of tax credits as we did last year, which should result in an adjusted tax rate similar to 2015. In the second quarter, we expect the adjusted tax rate to be about 30% due to timing and purchase of tax credits.
For the first quarter of 2016, weighted average shares outstanding on a diluted basis were approximately 217.5 million shares, down 5.2 million shares versus last year resulting in adjusted earnings per share diluted of $1.10 or an increase of about 1% versus a year ago. 
Turning now to the balance sheet and cash flow. At the end of the first quarter, net trading capital decreased versus last year's first quarter by $25 million. Accounts receivable was lower by $63 million and remains extremely current. Inventory was higher by $25 million and accounts payable declined by $13 million. Total capital additions including software, were $41.4 million in the first quarter. For the full year, we expect CapEx to be in the $285 million to $295 million range.
During the first quarter, depreciation and amortization was $60 million, and dividends paid were $122 million. In the first quarter, the company repurchased $304 million of outstanding shares. $20 million were repurchased against the $250 million authorization approved in February 2015, and $284 million were repurchased against the $500 million authorization approved in January 2016.
Cash on hand at the end of the quarter was $286 million, slightly lower than a year ago. As J.P. mentioned earlier, today we announced the acquisition of the barkTHINS Snacking Chocolate line. We expect that the acquisition will be dilutive in 2016 and '17 primarily due to the booked amortization of intangibles before turning accretive in 2018.
The off cash purchase price and the near-term earnings solution is partially offset by about $50 million to $60 million in cash flow tax benefits associated with the tax amortization of intangible assets in the basis step up. The tax amortization provides a future cash flow benefit. As a result, netting the benefit against the growth acquisition purchase price was also a deal multiple that is similar to other high growth CPG assets.
As J.P. summarized, over the remainder of the year, we have a lot of innovation, variety and use going into the marketplace. In-store merchandising and program activity is greater than last year, and advertising and related consumer marketing is expected to increase mid-to high single digits on a percentage basis versus last year over the next 3 quarters.
Therefore, for the full year, excluding unfavorable foreign currency exchange approximately 1 point and the barkTHINS acquisition of about 0.5 point, net sales growth is expected to accelerate and increase to around 2%. This is less than the previous estimate of about 3% due to the previously mentioned lower-than-expected U.S. nonseasonal CMG growth and economic headwinds in China.
The category -- the company expects gross margin to be slightly lower than last year due to unfavorable mix related with lower nonseasonal sales. The business productivity initiatives announced in June and the incremental CIP savings are on track and should result in reduction in SM&A expenses as we continue to leverage existing resources. As a result, the company expects adjusted earnings per share diluted to increase 3% to 4% including dilution from acquisitions of $0.05 to $0.06 per share and be in the $4.24 to $4.28 range. 
Before we open it up to Q&A, just a couple of on the second quarter. We expect constant currency net sales growth in Q2 to be greater than our full year outlook. However, the impact of unfavorable sales mix is greatest in the second quarter and may result in gross margin decline of 50 to 100 basis points. Additionally, advertising and related consumer marketing is expected to increase the most on a percentage basis versus last year in the second quarter. This is 1 of the levers in our marketing mix model that we believe will result in improved pull or retail takeaway in the second half of the year.
Therefore, we expect the EPS will be -- in the second quarter. Thank you for your time this morning, and we'll now take any questions you may have.

componenttext: Yes, so I think Andrew, you're in the right ballpark on the April to December  if you look at North America be probably a little over 3% to get there. So I think you've got that right. If you look at our plans in North America, they really do accelerate from the second half of the year, so a number of the investments that we've made really against combination of innovation and advertising should begin to show up there. Lots of solid in-store merchandising, so I think that's why we're optimistic on those second half of the year.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have actually 2 kind of specific accounting questions, maybe it's for you, Patricia, but I'm a little bit surprised that unless there's some kind of patent or large food service component, why would the noncash amortization expense be so high on this ac
componenttext: I have actually 2 kind of specific accounting questions, maybe it's for you, Patricia, but I'm a little bit surprised that unless there's some kind of patent or large food service component, why would the noncash amortization expense be so high on this acquisition? And then the second, the change in the accounting, I guess, from comprehensive other income to the -- what you're not doing, which is the exclusion of the volatility on the mark-to-market. So the $0.10 loss that you excluded, was there a similar type of loss a year ago? Or how do we kind of treat that, relative to how you've been doing it in the past?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, happy to answer that. Let me start with that 1. So up until last year, we used and met all the requirements to use GAAP hedge accounting. And that allowed us to put the volatility related to mark-to-market into our other comprehensive income or essen
componenttext: Yes, happy to answer that. Let me start with that 1. So up until last year, we used and met all the requirements to use GAAP hedge accounting. And that allowed us to put the volatility related to mark-to-market into our other comprehensive income or essentially on the balance sheet. It didn't close through the P&L. We proactively decided to go off of hedge accounting. You may or may not know this, but it's a very onerous requirement to make. A lot of our peers have done this and we looked at the cost benefit of doing this. We just didn't feel that it was worth it, especially since the standard cap getting tougher and tougher to meet. So what do we decided to do and we talked about this, I think, in the third and the fourth quarter, we would say off of hedge accounting and a lot of volatility to slow through the P&L. So that the change, but we also want to call that out for you so that you can see that because it's volatility is not consistent with the earnings that we use internally as well as prior periods. So that's why we adjusted it out in our adjusted GAAP or adjusted earnings. So when you look at the impact in the first quarter, there was no comparable piece of it to be adjusted out last time. However, on an adjusted basis, the 2 numbers are comparable. Just we got there by different means. Going forward, as we lap all the quarters, you continue to see it coming out of the adjustment in both periods.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you're going to exclude it from quarter-to-quarter and then in the fourth quarter, just have 1 big number, I guess, that adjusts for the year, something like that?
componenttext: So you're going to exclude it from quarter-to-quarter and then in the fourth quarter, just have 1 big number, I guess, that adjusts for the year, something like that?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, every quarter is different and being that out. You can have a quarter with positive, you can have a quarter with negative. What we want to do is match the ultimate mark-to-market that we have on the hedging contract with the period that we actually bu
componenttext: No, every quarter is different and being that out. You can have a quarter with positive, you can have a quarter with negative. What we want to do is match the ultimate mark-to-market that we have on the hedging contract with the period that we actually buy the underlying commodity. So for example, if we buy cocoa forward and in 1 quarter it might be some positive and next quarter it might be negative, by the time you buy the cocoa -- that's when we want to recognize the net impact of that volatility, so that it ties to the time that we are actually buying the cocoa and we get the net overall hedge price for the cocoa and that's the most common approach now in CPG in terms of the complexity related to commodity hedging.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on the second piece, on the barkTHINS?
componenttext: And then on the second piece, on the barkTHINS?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the barkTHINS, sorry. So yes, we basically -- we called out the fact that there's a very specific tax related to the barkTHINS acquisition. If you net that out, you would find that we're paying really in the same kind of multiple for a high-growth EB
componenttext: Yes, the barkTHINS, sorry. So yes, we basically -- we called out the fact that there's a very specific tax related to the barkTHINS acquisition. If you net that out, you would find that we're paying really in the same kind of multiple for a high-growth EBG asset that we as well as others, have made in the past. Typically, that's a 3x to 4x, and now what you're buying in all of these company essentially is the brand, creates the amortization of intangibles going forward as well as other cost related debt integration, but it's primarily the intangibles which gets amortized over the periods that the accounting requires absolute leads to the delusion.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from Chris Growe with Stifel.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had a question for you, if I could just talk about the new or incrementals cost saving programs. The level of incremental savings coming through, is that meant to offset inflation? And I should say, are the overall savings and inflation with the re
componenttext: I just had a question for you, if I could just talk about the new or incrementals cost saving programs. The level of incremental savings coming through, is that meant to offset inflation? And I should say, are the overall savings and inflation with the remain sort of it reinvested back in the business? Just trying to get a sense of how much of the spend for what and when and how much can be available for you to reinvest? And maybe if I could just as related to that, you talked about, I think, $10 million to $15 million of incremental savings in '16. Again, is that sort of earmarked for reinvestment? Just trying to understand how this incremental savings are going to be used this year?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's Patricia again. So the way I think about it is this. We've always had about $50 million to $70 million of productivity that comes due primarily in the supply chain arena. There's done a terrific job of offsetting underlying COGS inflations, so w
componenttext: Yes, it's Patricia again. So the way I think about it is this. We've always had about $50 million to $70 million of productivity that comes due primarily in the supply chain arena. There's done a terrific job of offsetting underlying COGS inflations, so we end up with flat or good margin expansion based on their efforts. What we've done starting in June of last year is we also had a productivity program that we announced and have been executing on here more in our corporate functions, and we got some benefit of that last year and we're going to get another $40 million of benefit from it this year. That's at the high-end of the range, by the way, of what we announced. We've been overdelivering on that. And then what we announced today is incremental savings, again, in SM&A category of $10 million to $15 million. Now as you know, most of our cost and SM&A, besides specific cost for advertising art cost related and we do have inflation, salary cost inflation and benefits inflation that hit as every year. Think of that as being about 3%. So what we'd like to be able to do is direct offset that, but in general, we're focusing on taking that discipline and continues improvement mindset that the supply chain guys have done so well and really migrating back over to all of our corporate functions to help them and help all of us offset inflation the same way that the supply chain guys have done. And yes, I would say that, that absolutely gives us the fuel to have those marketing and other advertising expenses that we need to ignite the market and push that second half growth that we are looking this year, so it's absolutely a big help for us in achieving that.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, just to be clear then, Patricia, you have -- you mentioned $40 million this year from a productivity program benefit, is that $40 million and $10 million to $15 million on top of that?
componenttext: Okay, just to be clear then, Patricia, you have -- you mentioned $40 million this year from a productivity program benefit, is that $40 million and $10 million to $15 million on top of that?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: No, actually, we get $50 million to $70 million normal productivity, Chris, the high end up to that $70 million, there's $10 million to $15 million on top of that, plus $40 million, $35 million or whatever it is from last year's June initiative as well.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: So think of it is total $120 million to $125 million but also pointing out that the $70 million is at the high-end of what we typically gotten every year, whereas the other 2 are specific to this year and less comparable to prior year's activities.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: Just a question, follow-up on the cost savings initiative or the expansion of it that you announced this morning. I think in the press release or maybe the prepared remarks, you talked a little bad about how some of that might be related to China. But I guess is just seems like given how different the sales and revenues are in that business now versus the original expectations that maybe there might be a bigger opportunity on cost savings. So can you just talk about, I guess, how much of the expansion of the savings program is related to China? And I guess, is there a potential that there be some something even above and beyond as we kind of look at in the future?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let's both Patricia and I will take that. First of all, as we continue to look at our China business, you heard in my remarks that we want to balance investments there with what we see as the opportunities. We know that the market right now is certainl
componenttext: So let's both Patricia and I will take that. First of all, as we continue to look at our China business, you heard in my remarks that we want to balance investments there with what we see as the opportunities. We know that the market right now is certainly challenge, but at the same time, we're in the midst of working through our integration. We want to make sure that we make the decisions there for the long-term. And as we continue to get familiar with our overall go-to-market strategy and how we brought the 2 businesses together, we just want to be prudent in terms of making sure we're making good decisions. At the same time, we do believe that there's opportunities within our China business to go further than we have at the current point in time. So I'll let Patricia, if she wants, to add any additional perspective.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The 1 thing that I'd add to that is really, pointing out the progress that's been made and bringing the 2 organizations together. While there were clearly some disappointment in our acquisition of Golden Monkey, the fundamentals of why we wanted are still
componenttext: The 1 thing that I'd add to that is really, pointing out the progress that's been made and bringing the 2 organizations together. While there were clearly some disappointment in our acquisition of Golden Monkey, the fundamentals of why we wanted are still there. We really like the aspects of the traditional trade. We really like the 2 brands that they bring to our Golden Monkey München monkey, and we think that's a very good complement to our strength in the 3 brands that we have a new chocolate business in China and our focus there on the modern trade a little bit over indexed to hypermarket, which we can certainly see in our results. So the key mirrors on a nice job of bringing that together. That's -- while that's generated some cost savings and frankly, we're still looking, and I think we'll find some more, I think the really important thing is bringing the 2 businesses together to a point of strength that each individually have and that's what J.P. I would add to J.P.'s remarks about balance, that's the parts that were balancing.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Robert Moskow with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Robert Moskow with Crédit Suisse.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, J.P., the article in the Washington Journal today and also your comments and your acquisition point to a lot of strategic efforts to expand snacks. But the comments on the call are about slowing category growth and candy, mint and gum. And I'm just w
componenttext: Hey, J.P., the article in the Washington Journal today and also your comments and your acquisition point to a lot of strategic efforts to expand snacks. But the comments on the call are about slowing category growth and candy, mint and gum. And I'm just wondering, it seems like a pretty critical time for the category. You say that you need to reaccelerate the growth. Can you give us a little bit more color on this meaningful launch that you talked about in the back half of the year? What's the marketing objective of that launch? What's the risk that you're taking, the investment that your meaning to make? And are you worried that your core operations might take the eye off the ball a little bit if all the efforts are on stacking?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first of all, thank you for the question and I'll try to add as much perspective as I can on some level. I'm not going to go into as much detail as you'd like just for competitive reasons. But let me put it in perspective that snacks today, if you look
componenttext: So first of all, thank you for the question and I'll try to add as much perspective as I can on some level. I'm not going to go into as much detail as you'd like just for competitive reasons. But let me put it in perspective that snacks today, if you look at the pure snacking type stuff outside of confectionery and outside of our grocery businesses, is really only 2% of our total business. If you put in those other pantry-type businesses, spreads, et cetera, it's about 9% of the business. So confectionery is at the core of who we are and what we do. What we've seen is we've continued to demand and landscape work. If there's an interesting area around what we call snackfection and if you look at some of our recent, like the Reese's mix and bytes products, those have been terrific for us. They don't show up in our market share because they're actually captured in snacks. But we're very, very pleased with how we've progressed there. So I think that what you should take away it is that we are very focused against our core -- innovating around our core and executing against the fundamentals and very competitive and changing snacking environment. But we really see an immediate opportunity in this area of snackfection for the company. And then as you look at how consumers relationship with food has changed, we recognize that the snacking continuum has grown. And so products like Krave, which we're learning a lot from and are very pleased, will always be part of our test and learn and grow strategies, but it doesn't take away from our core focus. And so around portability, one of the things you see is there's new users and consumer rotations that are in -- that we see is a big opportunity. So confection has always been a part of snacking. I think there is been some confusion around when we talk about snacking, it's a bit something different than confection and the fact of the matter is confection has always been snacking, with the biggest part of the snack wheel. And so these new occasions arrive and the opportunities are rates for the company, we want to be able to take advantage of them, succeed to the brands we have and also be able to expand and some of these new segments, and there's a significant blurring across this total snacking category that we think has added some of the lumpiness and challenges for the category as you see so many new items and choices for the consumer. And I think it's all sorts single mark important thing for us is to continue to build on our brand relevance and the consumers have relationships with our brand and that's why we like to talk about being a consumer-centric and brand-building company. We don't think we've lost anything there, but we certainly would tell you that there's lots of opportunities, and we have to be at our best to take advantage of them.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: As quick follow-up, Brookside Farms the data has -- look very good. Can you tell us was happening there?
componenttext: As quick follow-up, Brookside Farms the data has -- look very good. Can you tell us was happening there?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there's a couple of things, I let Michele join in here if she has anything to add, but as we look at the Brookside brand, we're really pleased with the growth of the brands. It's done terrific in terms of this establishing the #2 or 3 dark c
componenttext: Well, I think there's a couple of things, I let Michele join in here if she has anything to add, but as we look at the Brookside brand, we're really pleased with the growth of the brands. It's done terrific in terms of this establishing the #2 or 3 dark chocolate brand in the category. It's got great repeat purchase, somewhere in the range of like 50%, which is really, really high. If the head of our acquisition strategy. Now we have lost some distribution in the club channel. We also believe that, as we have expanded it, we need to continue to work on the brand positioning some. And you'll see that we've got a whole new advertising effort there. And then we also probably with tell you that we have expanded some of the offerings, maybe a little bit ahead of ourselves, and we need to make sure that we just continue to work on brand composition. So as we do that, we continue to have a lot of competence in the brand. I don't if Michele was to add anything, but those would be my comments.

componenttext: I had a couple of follow-ups and then a question. So just to be clear to Chris Growe's question, will the incremental cost savings be reinvested back into the business in 2017 through '19? So forget the '16 numbers, you answered that well, but I'm not clear on the '17 to '19 period.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a big part of -- I guess I'd say it this way, it's a part of our long-term EPS guidance. But at the base of that long-term EPS guidance is an investment philosophy about gross in our core and adjacent categories. That's the fundamental driver. S
componenttext: Yes, it's a big part of -- I guess I'd say it this way, it's a part of our long-term EPS guidance. But at the base of that long-term EPS guidance is an investment philosophy about gross in our core and adjacent categories. That's the fundamental driver. So I would say yes, it's absolutely part of our whole algorithm. It needs to be a balanced algorithm between sales growth and cost discipline.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean it's not a small number. I mean, at the high end, it's 3.5 point of EPS growth so I appreciate that but it's a large number. Second follow-up number is on China, when I just distribution rough math, it feels like that business is losing like $30 mi
componenttext: I mean it's not a small number. I mean, at the high end, it's 3.5 point of EPS growth so I appreciate that but it's a large number. Second follow-up number is on China, when I just distribution rough math, it feels like that business is losing like $30 million in the quarter, just something like that. I think while your other businesses are profitable, so as you quite a large loss. You mentioned, J.P., that you would align the cost to the opportunity. But really, simply, are the savings that you would expect to happen in the China operations, are they embedded in this new cost savings program?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start with that and the maybe J.P. can give a little more color around China. Yes, part of 10 to 15 incremental savings that we announced, and I think we're also sort of made clear we're continue to look at balancing the cost structure against the op
componenttext: I'll start with that and the maybe J.P. can give a little more color around China. Yes, part of 10 to 15 incremental savings that we announced, and I think we're also sort of made clear we're continue to look at balancing the cost structure against the opportunities in the market, and then that may result in further savings going forward, but that's a work-in-progress. And that's something we're going to talk about were announced today. With that, let me put it over to J.P. how we see the overall long-term opportunity in the market.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, David, there's a couple of things that I would say. First of all, China for us is probably the best market for a period of time. While the profile may change, I think that well, for some period of time, continue to be in a brand building typ
componenttext: Yes, I think, David, there's a couple of things that I would say. First of all, China for us is probably the best market for a period of time. While the profile may change, I think that well, for some period of time, continue to be in a brand building type mode. Let me just take a step back and maybe clear up a couple of things in terms of how I view what we're currently doing in China. So the first most important thing we needed to do following the recent acquisition, we just gained control of the business, as we've all been quite open and talked about some surprises there and things that we weren't very pleased with, but we feel very good about the efforts of the team has made and that we gained control of what we had there. But we're in the process of creating a solid foundation. It's around work structure. It's around the systems we need to run the business and a big piece of integration. And so that creating the foundation is really where we're at. And then the third phase is that we have to execute against the business we have. Unfortunately, it's a volatile market with some uncertainty right now, so when I talk about being balanced, we have to make sure that we can afford the organization structure and our go-to-market strategies there. But listen, we believe in emerging middle class, we believe in marginalization, we believe that these are markets that over time, we want to be in. So from a quarter-to-quarter basis, it may be tough to make some of those strategic decisions. And then if we execute well, results come. And we'll be able to then do the things that we do well and grow our brands in the market and grow with the category and overcome some of these, what I would believe are more short-term challenges. That's really -- I think importantly, that's how I think about it. And so that's the best way for, I think, you guys to think about it as well.

componenttext: If I could just sneak in 1 last clarification and You mentioned in both of your script and in the press release, there's the potential for upside to the outlook. Are you saying that Q1 trends are just not kind of representative and they really need to get into the rest of the year to understand where the sales growth is? And you've taken it down because of what Q1 has done, but it's almost like you don't believe it. Or something with this upside to the outlook comment. Can you help me out?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, I think David, what I would tell you is that as we look at the marketplace and what we see it happening in Q1, that we're being prudent in the comments that we're making. We're optimistic within our plan that we always want to grow share ahead of
componenttext: Yes, no, I think David, what I would tell you is that as we look at the marketplace and what we see it happening in Q1, that we're being prudent in the comments that we're making. We're optimistic within our plan that we always want to grow share ahead of the market. And that's what we're going to be challenged with it. And again, if we also believe that we delivered against some of the other cost initiatives and the things that we have, that we'll be able to meet the guidance that we've given you. So I don't want you to take that comment differently than what we've said with regard to our guidance other than we have some optimism. And I'll let Michele talk a little bit about the second half and give you a sense of how she thinking about it as well.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As we look at the year to go, we have a lot of activity. As you know, we're not a versus prior year in Q1, so we lined up a lot of our investment with what's to come. We're rapidly expanding behind the capacity investment we made last year and the a
componenttext: Sure. As we look at the year to go, we have a lot of activity. As you know, we're not a versus prior year in Q1, so we lined up a lot of our investment with what's to come. We're rapidly expanding behind the capacity investment we made last year and the advertising with a new campaign that you just going on here and now. We've actually been constrained and not actually even able to service enough. With merchandising because of how well those items have done, so we're really going to be able to get behind that in a bigger way as the year goes on. Big catches launching we're sponsored the Olympics, which is going to be huge for merchandising perspective and as we told you guys last year, where we started to see some softness and share at the end of the year, we made a decision to invest, to be more competitive and just given the timeline it takes to get those dollars into marketplace, that really kicks in beginning in May. We have the birth execution that's really going to expand, so it is a lot of execution going the back of the year that we have a lot of confidence in, and we're cautiously optimistic about some of the potential anomalies we may see in Q1 in February, but we want to be prudent about the marketplace and balancing that with the aggressive programming we have the rest of the year.

componenttext: Yes, we think we have the opportunity and it's a very viable consumer proposition that's grounded in the very on trend area of clean label and fully sustainable profile. It's a less sweet kind of case profile. I would liken it somewhat to Brookside and what we did with Brookside when we purchased that. It allows us, strategically to expand into mass premium, to have a product that's is very well-liked by millennials and to capture that opportunity to just expand beyond that.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And my next question is just, how do you decide on what you think a structural versus short-term issues? And what evidence that you have that some of these issues are short-term? I'm just trying to figure out very by the coming from in terms of how to kin
componenttext: And my next question is just, how do you decide on what you think a structural versus short-term issues? And what evidence that you have that some of these issues are short-term? I'm just trying to figure out very by the coming from in terms of how to kind of -- have your long-term strategy in terms of the sales, but you keep on saying that from headwinds and short term, I just kind of figure out how you think about them as being short-term versus structural and what evidence do you have?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if you look across what's happening a total space, I think these are more cyclical versus structural issues. We continue to have a lot of enthusiasm for all the advantages of the category that we're in. I think if you look at the history of,
componenttext: Well, I think if you look across what's happening a total space, I think these are more cyclical versus structural issues. We continue to have a lot of enthusiasm for all the advantages of the category that we're in. I think if you look at the history of, I'll call it snacking as well as confectionery, it's always been changing. You've seen a number of different types of trends and things in the market. I think 1 of the events that makes this current period of time unique is the amount of choice that there is in the market relative to what I think we've historically seen. That means the trial has moved around a lot. At the same time, you have some different things impacting retailers and we've come out of a period of time some uncertainty in economies. And so I think all of those things have made it a more challenging environment, but I don't think those are structural things that were major changes taking place. Now you've heard me talk about consumers have a changing relationship with food. So much of that is really around transparency, as much as it is anything else, where people are wanting to understand ingredients better than they ever have before. As manufacturers, we're all responding to that, certainly, we are as well. But as I take a step back, and's just look at the overall industry as well as the category that we compete and I think many of the things that are happening are far more cyclical than I would think about as structural.

componenttext: So what are you able to estimate the underlying CMG category growth in North America if you flesh out all the time a shift and so on? Are you able to get about number? And a quick follow-up, can you comment on how you're planning to respond to the requirement of the mandatory labeling of foods containing genetically modified ingredients that due to come in July?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, so I'll start with the latter and then go to the first part of your question. So we have -- so I'll speak specifically to Hershey. We have products that we'll need to meet the Vermont labeling requirements that contains GMO ingredients. And then we
componenttext: Sure, so I'll start with the latter and then go to the first part of your question. So we have -- so I'll speak specifically to Hershey. We have products that we'll need to meet the Vermont labeling requirements that contains GMO ingredients. And then we have some products that don't need to be labeled. So appropriately, we will abide by what's happening in Vermont. And label as appropriate. And then I hope that at the federal level, there is clarity to this question because it becomes a interstate commerce issue if you have different states taking different approaches would make it very confusing for manufacturing -- manufacturers. And so I do hope that there's some clarity around how labeling happens if it's required on a broader basis. And then as you know, we've committed to 2 transparency. We are very big supporters of smart label, which gives consumers to engage with our brand. And understand what our -- the ingredients that, et cetera, so that's how we'll deal with Vermont. And then on the category growth rates, I'll let Michele talk to that with regard to North America.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we're estimating that the category growth rate in North America would be between 2% and 2.5%, which is about where we've seen it over the past couple of years, a little bit on the later side, if we go down to the 2% range. We anticipate that our t
componenttext: Yes, so we're estimating that the category growth rate in North America would be between 2% and 2.5%, which is about where we've seen it over the past couple of years, a little bit on the later side, if we go down to the 2% range. We anticipate that our takeaway would be greater than that such that we we'll gain a little bit of share. And obviously, with the Easter timing issue that occurred on a year-to-date basis and some of the softness we saw in Q1, we are still waiting to see how that plays out, but that's our long-term estimate, is 2% to 2.5% and that's what were thinking it will be for the year.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, we can kind of in this, but I do think that we are seeing a more competitive environment than we have seen for a period of time. We note that in 2015, we probably lost a little bit on quality or is versus where we would have liked to be have
componenttext:
Well, again, we can kind of in this, but I do think that we are seeing a more competitive environment than we have seen for a period of time. We note that in 2015, we probably lost a little bit on quality or is versus where we would have liked to be have been. And so as we look at the opportunities and landscape in 2016, we don't want to have that happen to us again. One of the comments I would just make is that there's less space as retailers have clean floors, so the competitiveness to get that space is not just within our category. It's really across multiple categories. And that's put a premium on the cost of, I'll call it, doing business in some classes of trade.
Thank you very much for joining us this morning, and the IR team will be available for any follow-up calls you may have.
