headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You released -- you mentioned marketing to authenticity and simplicity of ingredients. Are consumers telling you that this is a friction point for your brands and for the category? Are you solving that perception issue? And do you intend to do a renovatio
componenttext: You released -- you mentioned marketing to authenticity and simplicity of ingredients. Are consumers telling you that this is a friction point for your brands and for the category? Are you solving that perception issue? And do you intend to do a renovation of any of your products associated with this message?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So for certain consumers in the marketplace, certainty, authenticity and simple ingredients is clearly something that they're looking for. And so, our approach is really just think about our portfolio that we have and make sure that we have choices for ev
componenttext: So for certain consumers in the marketplace, certainty, authenticity and simple ingredients is clearly something that they're looking for. And so, our approach is really just think about our portfolio that we have and make sure that we have choices for everyone along the spectrum. So certainly , Queen label, simple ingredients and that appeals so that consumer. And as I believe you're aware, we evolved our Hershey products, which was very close to Simple Ingredients, took at all the way there and we're actually going to begin advertising about in the third quarter. So we believe that certain products of ours, certainly, like a Jolly Rancher are never going to be simple ingredients, so we will have a full portfolio that gives consumers meaningful other choices.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just a follow-up, is the SNACK-FECTION innovation that you're talking about later in, is that an extension of the confectionery brand into healthier snacking? And if so, do you feel like indulgent brands can move into better-for-you?
componenttext: And just a follow-up, is the SNACK-FECTION innovation that you're talking about later in, is that an extension of the confectionery brand into healthier snacking? And if so, do you feel like indulgent brands can move into better-for-you?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I would say that it is -- the innovation that's coming up really SNACK-FECTION in terms of blurring -- the blurring that's occurring between various snack categories. Think salty snack an infection or other categories, cookies and confection, et cetera
componenttext: So I would say that it is -- the innovation that's coming up really SNACK-FECTION in terms of blurring -- the blurring that's occurring between various snack categories. Think salty snack an infection or other categories, cookies and confection, et cetera, so it's really leveraging the fact that consumers are looking for more of those complex eats and opportunities to play at the seams between categories. I think there are -- that largely our confection or hard-core mainstream confection brands will continue to offer primarily indulgent benefits, but there are some places where I think there's a little bit of crossover. For example, Snack Mix certainly has nuts, pretzels, et cetera, and consumers are seeing that a little closer to having some food value than a straight chocolate.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Bryan Spillane with Bank of America.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Bryan Spillane with Bank of America.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess a question just following up on Andrew Lazar's question. Michele, can you tease out for us how much of the category weakness or the category being sort of softer than it had been historically is coming from immediate consumption versus at-home con
componenttext: I guess a question just following up on Andrew Lazar's question. Michele, can you tease out for us how much of the category weakness or the category being sort of softer than it had been historically is coming from immediate consumption versus at-home consumption? I get the idea of being just seems like there is a vast amount of choice as a consumer goes to the front end with a lot of products that are near or someone close to what your base products are. So just trying to get a sense for how much of the work you need to do is really in getting immediate consumption changed or is it really equal, both at-home and immediate consumption?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean I don't think that we are seeing a strong skew to one type of consumption versus the other. So as we look at our instant consumable business, it's relatively flat. So a lot of that can be skewed by the support that goes behind the business rel
componenttext: Yes, I mean I don't think that we are seeing a strong skew to one type of consumption versus the other. So as we look at our instant consumable business, it's relatively flat. So a lot of that can be skewed by the support that goes behind the business relative to merchandising and certainly, the Queen -- Queen floor policies have probably impacted the take home side of the business a bit more. So we continue to focus on big scale events, our focus on our core brands and core back types, both in terms of take-home and instant consumables but we aren't releasing a dramatic trend one way or the other on that front.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Alexia Howard with Bernstein.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Alexia Howard with Bernstein.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I ask about the recent CVS announcement that they're going to be putting quite a lot more better-for-you snacking in the front area of the store? I think they talked about are placing about 25% of the area that was previously targeted at candy. I gues
componenttext: Can I ask about the recent CVS announcement that they're going to be putting quite a lot more better-for-you snacking in the front area of the store? I think they talked about are placing about 25% of the area that was previously targeted at candy. I guess, what -- how do you react to an announcement like that? Is there a risk that those kind of move might spread elsewhere in the industry?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first of all, we partner with our retail customers very closely, so announcements like that aren't surprises to us. They actually look to us to help them to optimize their total box and their total sales across snacking. If you look at that CVS example
componenttext: So first of all, we partner with our retail customers very closely, so announcements like that aren't surprises to us. They actually look to us to help them to optimize their total box and their total sales across snacking. If you look at that CVS example, that -- you might be surprised to learn that on that one, for example, we are netting out in a neutral position from an SKU perspective so as we have broadened our portfolio to have offerings like barkTHINS, Krave, Meat Bars, think about refreshment portfolio, those are actually allowing us to remain neutral on an SKU basis and really just offering consumers broader choice, both for across the CVS portfolio but also the Hershey portfolio. So certainly, it's something that we're focused on. I wouldn't tell you that it's not something that we are -- that we have an eye on. But we are really thinking about the fact that that is out there and making sure that we have the right plans in place to continue to drive our confectionery and broader snacking portfolio.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from John Baumgartner with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question is from John Baumgartner with Wells Fargo.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michele, maybe to ask the U.S. consumption question a different way, just going back to your consumer analytics around segmenting out into various buckets, the loyalists, the occasion and so on, of the category's deceleration, can you pinpoint where on th
componenttext: Michele, maybe to ask the U.S. consumption question a different way, just going back to your consumer analytics around segmenting out into various buckets, the loyalists, the occasion and so on, of the category's deceleration, can you pinpoint where on that spectrum with the pressure has really emerged that maybe at the first past? And then as a follow-up course correction from your how should we think about that we could be spent more back against the brands either promo or advertising, given the substitute pressure coming into your -- the snacking categories?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I'd say, I mean, relative to the marketing mix, as J.P. mentioned, I think we are really still working through with evolving consumer choices and the evolving retailer landscape, just really optimizing that mix. So I would tell you that we continu
componenttext: Yes, so I'd say, I mean, relative to the marketing mix, as J.P. mentioned, I think we are really still working through with evolving consumer choices and the evolving retailer landscape, just really optimizing that mix. So I would tell you that we continue to learn every quarter. We've gotten more sophisticated models in place to help us to better understand the interaction between all of that, but that scenario will continue to work on and I think make some continuous improvement going forward.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So one thing that I would add to that is that as we've seen innovation across the snack wheel. So remember what we said earlier is the box is up about 1.8%. Snack wheel is actually running ahead of that. And then there's part of the snack wheel that are,
componenttext: So one thing that I would add to that is that as we've seen innovation across the snack wheel. So remember what we said earlier is the box is up about 1.8%. Snack wheel is actually running ahead of that. And then there's part of the snack wheel that are, obviously, outperforming others and what you could link that to in almost every instance is the quality of the innovation. So I would actually say that has been a more critical element in a more competitive and space constrained world, that that's giving certain brands and categories an opportunity to be available and consumers are responding to that. But for me, the really good news is that the snack wheel continues to do well. We just have to make sure that we're working hard and winning our part of it.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Mario from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll go next to Mario from Deutsche Bank.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to ask, with respect to China, can you give us an update on how you stand with your current distributors? Are you satisfied with the set up that you have? Are they meeting expectations? And then beyond that, given the recent Mondelez announcem
componenttext: So I wanted to ask, with respect to China, can you give us an update on how you stand with your current distributors? Are you satisfied with the set up that you have? Are they meeting expectations? And then beyond that, given the recent Mondelez announcement into their entry to the market, do you anticipate any changes to your strategy or to overall category dynamics in the upcoming quarters?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, in terms of any entrance into the category, the China market is still a young market relative to consumption per capita. So really, as long as we're all working hard on category development, that's probably a good thing. So frankly, that's h
componenttext: First of all, in terms of any entrance into the category, the China market is still a young market relative to consumption per capita. So really, as long as we're all working hard on category development, that's probably a good thing. So frankly, that's how we think about it. In terms of our acquisition and integration work there, I would tell you that we're making really good progress against the integration. Some of that work is still continuing, obviously, but we really gone through and done the sales organization work and combined those. That's gone well. We've taken what was the Hershey piece and the Golden Monkey piece and really try to consolidate those distributors. So it's a bit blended from where we've started with Golden Monkey and Hershey, but we really feel as though our go-to-market position is in the best shape that it's been. We're selling things. So as I like to think about it kind of in a simple way, are we making stuff, shipping it, selling it and collecting money? And all of those things are working for us. So I think that the market in China, as you've heard from a lot of companies, is pressured. I think we would align with that. The consumer, obviously, has to show up, but we feel good about where we're at. And we'll continue, though, I would say, as I've said before, make sure we're rightsizing our businesses to the opportunities. And certainly, we'll continue to focus against that. And then, as you think about the overall P&L, the impact that China restructure on our P&L this year is really relatively limited, so we think that'll continue to also help us as we go forward.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Jonathan Finney from Consumer Edge Research.
componenttext: Our next question is from Jonathan Finney from Consumer Edge Research.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: J.P., wanted to circle back, for a second, on your answer to Andrew Lazar's question on inventory, even though I'm picturing David Driscoll in my mind. The -- like you, I just, J.P., I just can't stop picturing. But the -- what kind of -- when you look at
componenttext: J.P., wanted to circle back, for a second, on your answer to Andrew Lazar's question on inventory, even though I'm picturing David Driscoll in my mind. The -- like you, I just, J.P., I just can't stop picturing. But the -- what kind of -- when you look at both the category and your takeaway, what sort of consumer take away in North America for the third quarter, fourth quarter, maybe into next year, do you have in mind when you think about the kind of -- this kind of shipment growth going in? Just trying to get in -- what does that mean for kind of market share? And what would be sort of good success metrics for you going forward for the next 6, 12 months there?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you think about the second half of the year and if -- first of all, the inventory perspective I gave you, I'm not trying a lot to that. That's certainly how it is. If you think about the second half of the year, with Halloween and seasons, we have
componenttext: Yes, if you think about the second half of the year and if -- first of all, the inventory perspective I gave you, I'm not trying a lot to that. That's certainly how it is. If you think about the second half of the year, with Halloween and seasons, we have very good visibility to that. We know what that's going to look like. Same thing would be with Holiday. And then, also remembers, we've talked about a significant innovation in Q4. We benefit from the volume of that as we begin to build distribution and of course the merchandising activity is after that. So as we move through the year, you have the benefit of that volume that won't necessarily be a piece of the take away, so you might have a bit of a disconnect there in the second half. It shouldn't be significant. But as we've talked about our expectations in terms of the balance of the year, it does take into the consideration the first half of the year, where we've seen the category growth be and that's probably where you also seen some of the moderation on the outlook and expectation there. I don't know if anyone else wants to add something to that.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean I'd just say we expect to continue to see some kind of a slow sequential build in take away as we  further into the year.
componenttext: Yes, I mean I'd just say we expect to continue to see some kind of a slow sequential build in take away as we  further into the year.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the fourth quarter will be better than the third, obviously, just because of our strength in seasons and then to J.P.'s point, net sales, intuitively, should be of the bit better than takeaway because of the big ones that we have made in the year.
componenttext: I think the fourth quarter will be better than the third, obviously, just because of our strength in seasons and then to J.P.'s point, net sales, intuitively, should be of the bit better than takeaway because of the big ones that we have made in the year.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Matthew Grainger with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll go next to Matthew Grainger with Morgan Stanley.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: J.P. and Michele, you talked about the pipeline of innovation that you have coming up in chocolate and snacking in the second half. And when we look at the CMG trends at the subcategory level, we're actually seeing some of the strongest growth in non-choc
componenttext: J.P. and Michele, you talked about the pipeline of innovation that you have coming up in chocolate and snacking in the second half. And when we look at the CMG trends at the subcategory level, we're actually seeing some of the strongest growth in non-chocolate and your own sales there have been dramatically weaker. And I know you've been in a position of meaning to be selective about where you're focusing your investments, but can you just speak to your approach toward how you're thinking about non-chocolate at the moment? Any concerns that you're starving that side of the business and losing too much market share in the short term?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I would say yes to that question. As we made prioritization choices across the portfolio, we've made a decision to pull back a bit in non-chocolate and I think, we are reevaluating the choice, certainly, as we speak. I think we pulled back at a ti
componenttext: Yes, so I would say yes to that question. As we made prioritization choices across the portfolio, we've made a decision to pull back a bit in non-chocolate and I think, we are reevaluating the choice, certainly, as we speak. I think we pulled back at a time that some others in the marketplace actually accelerates. So as we look next year, we are certainly adjusting our approach. We think that variety and news are absolutely key and that's really where our focus will be, to dial-up efforts, in combination with the strong innovation that we feel really good about on chocolate around things like core news, like Big Kat, Reese's Pieces Cup and then big sustainable scale innovation on chocolate like the big one that we have coming toward the end of the year. But you will see us dial up the focus on non-chocolate next year.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and just I'm not sure if it's possible to talk more about timing. I mean, how quickly can you replenish the innovation pipeline? Is that something that takes a few quarters? Or is it possible that it might, given where you are, that it might take lo
componenttext: Okay, and just I'm not sure if it's possible to talk more about timing. I mean, how quickly can you replenish the innovation pipeline? Is that something that takes a few quarters? Or is it possible that it might, given where you are, that it might take longer?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, on non-chocolate, I would tell you, I wouldn't expect to see activity this year. It will be into next year. I'd rather not go into the specific timing just for competitive reasons, but definitely, it would be a couple quarters. We have a pipeline in
componenttext: Yes, on non-chocolate, I would tell you, I wouldn't expect to see activity this year. It will be into next year. I'd rather not go into the specific timing just for competitive reasons, but definitely, it would be a couple quarters. We have a pipeline in place. And, so it's really a model of dialing that up and getting it into the marketplace.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question from Jason English with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question from Jason English with Goldman Sachs.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a couple questions. Let me start one sort on the higher level. A lot of talk on the call and clearly seen the data of short of shifting growth within I think you call it the snacking wheel. I guess I have a question on pricing within confection. Is the
componenttext: So a couple questions. Let me start one sort on the higher level. A lot of talk on the call and clearly seen the data of short of shifting growth within I think you call it the snacking wheel. I guess I have a question on pricing within confection. Is there any concern that that price gaps between alternative snacking solutions may be an issue? And any implications in terms of pricing power going forward as we certainly see a number of your key inputs moving higher recently?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I -- so let me talk about the pricing piece a little bit and then we can touch again on some of the snack wheel stuff. But I think what we've seen is that if you call on the last call, we talked about the number of new entrants that's happened, espec
componenttext: Yes, I -- so let me talk about the pricing piece a little bit and then we can touch again on some of the snack wheel stuff. But I think what we've seen is that if you call on the last call, we talked about the number of new entrants that's happened, especially in the snack bars relative to the whole snacking space. And some of those entrants, I think, have gotten trial not only because they're new, but I think there's also been a different pricing delta that the obstacle to trial has been lowered. And so, I think the level of activity probably speaks more to what the net value to the customer could have been across all of the different options and opportunities available to them. So I think going forward, while we are looking a lot at our whole revenue management approach and making sure that we really got that right, we're thinking a lot about this particular question. And I do think there's some influence there as there's been trial in the category, and I would just come back to my other comments around innovation is, that it is very clear that those brands and companies who have done well in innovation have gotten a disproportionate share of the consumer's attention. And those -- that's the real quality driver, in my mind. So if you come back to what I said earlier, we're really, really focused against 3 things in our business model and it's the innovation. We're really looking at our marketing mix model because based on the previous question, you're right, allocation and resources across different pieces of the business. I think there's some things -- we learned there. And of course, we want to run approval business and invest in our brands and our people. And those are the 3 things I think you should take away from what we're really talking about today.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. One more then I'll pass it on. On the innovation front, it's been a long time since we've seen a successful new candy bar lunch sustaining market. So can you talk more about what's differentiated about this cookie layer crunch product that
componenttext: That's helpful. One more then I'll pass it on. On the innovation front, it's been a long time since we've seen a successful new candy bar lunch sustaining market. So can you talk more about what's differentiated about this cookie layer crunch product that leaves you to believe that it can really be a sustainable success?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, why don't I have Michele talk about that. Then I think if you go back to how she talked about it within the seems of pure confection and as you might think about other snacking opportunities, that that's what we think is really unique about how this
componenttext: Yes, why don't I have Michele talk about that. Then I think if you go back to how she talked about it within the seems of pure confection and as you might think about other snacking opportunities, that that's what we think is really unique about how this is positioned. We'd like to see it source volume from maybe some new places that stretches us a bit from just the core, but I'll let Michele speak to that.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so our most successful innovations are clearly grounded in deep consumer insights and we've certainly gone -- leveraged a lot of insights and research as we've developed this proposition and feel quick good about it. As J.P. said, it really does play
componenttext: Yes, so our most successful innovations are clearly grounded in deep consumer insights and we've certainly gone -- leveraged a lot of insights and research as we've developed this proposition and feel quick good about it. As J.P. said, it really does play between those themes in SNACK-FECTION of marrying cookie and chocolate, obviously. And those really plays on some deep insights around pallet. If you think about the kind of creamy crunchy sweet and salty we see in the marketplace has demonstrated a lot of growth and we're seeing with younger consumers in particular, there is strong interest in complex eats that this really delivers upon. That will provide incremental usage versus our portfolio, which tends to be more of a -- kind of a straight, creamy pallet. So if you think about the actual expense consumers are looking for and the new users we're able to bring, we're feeling really good about it.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Next we'll go to with Stifel.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just have 2 follow-ups. I guess I want to clear back to the earlier question. If you quantify the effect on U.S. sales in the second quarter, like what good come out of the third quarter as you pull forward in the sales? And maybe if I could add just a
componenttext: I just have 2 follow-ups. I guess I want to clear back to the earlier question. If you quantify the effect on U.S. sales in the second quarter, like what good come out of the third quarter as you pull forward in the sales? And maybe if I could add just a follow-up question to an earlier question, as you think about all these cost savings, is there a level of marketing you're trying to achieve? Or how should we frame, at least, the potential to reinvest some of these savings back into the business?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so let me start by -- we're not going to quantify the sales impact, but I think you might be thinking it might be larger than -- by the nature of your question, it sounds like you might be thinking it's a larger than it is. On the cost savings piece,
componenttext: Yes, so let me start by -- we're not going to quantify the sales impact, but I think you might be thinking it might be larger than -- by the nature of your question, it sounds like you might be thinking it's a larger than it is. On the cost savings piece, we really want to look at all the levers of our cost. done historically good job of our costs savings. We continue to focus on that and that will actually be the biggest driver. We need to extend that into other areas, including our SM&A that excludes our marketing part of our business. And then on marketing, it's going to be a combination of continuing to want to invest as a brand building company but doing that in an ever smarter way and making sure that everyone of those dollars works for us. World's changing pretty quickly and we're just going to need to continuously reevaluate the roles of each of our -- each lever that we have in marketing.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one follow-up in the U.S. you have 3.5% growth and I look at your take away in the quarter, it's around 0.5%. So I'm just trying to put those numbers together. Am I looking at it the wrong way or?
componenttext: And just one follow-up in the U.S. you have 3.5% growth and I look at your take away in the quarter, it's around 0.5%. So I'm just trying to put those numbers together. Am I looking at it the wrong way or?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think because of timing of some of the things, it's probably easier to look at it on a year-to-date basis. And when you look at it on a year-to-date basis, there's actually virtually no gap between our -- there's a very small gap between our take a
componenttext: Yes, I think because of timing of some of the things, it's probably easier to look at it on a year-to-date basis. And when you look at it on a year-to-date basis, there's actually virtually no gap between our -- there's a very small gap between our take away and our sales.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: What can expect to hear from you folks on your Analyst Day coming up, assuming you're still going to have it? Do you think you'll give us a little more clarity on the cost structure reductions that you're planning and maybe even some more detail on some of this marketing mix modeling. And I think people are going to care, Michele, if this is a message that advertising promotion or really just advertising kind of comes down a little bit, I think we all remember 2005 and 2006 when it went on too far, so will you give us more clarity on that regard also?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Rob, it's Mark and I let Michele and J.P. talk to those business -- some of the business drivers and investments that you referenced. As it relates to the Analyst Day, you're right, there hasn't been a date put out there. I mean there's, obviously, a
componenttext: Hey, Rob, it's Mark and I let Michele and J.P. talk to those business -- some of the business drivers and investments that you referenced. As it relates to the Analyst Day, you're right, there hasn't been a date put out there. I mean there's, obviously, a lot of moving parts and you know that we're absolutely focused on the business and doing all the right things for the near and long term, as we continue to do. But as soon as we have a date, we'll communicate it.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would just very quickly talk about on the cost side, we've talked about very clearly what we expect in 2016. It's a bit early to get into some of the specifics of the additional work that we're doing, but we are -- we have a process in place and we
componenttext: Yes, I would just very quickly talk about on the cost side, we've talked about very clearly what we expect in 2016. It's a bit early to get into some of the specifics of the additional work that we're doing, but we are -- we have a process in place and we're looking at all the costs and opportunities we have, literally, across the entire business, line by line and we want to ultimately make sure that we can make out the investments in our brands, aligned with the opportunities that are in front of us. I think you'll continue to hear is be very consumer and brand focused and yet at the same time, we'll also be margin focused but we have to be able to afford those investments. But as we think it's appropriate to build brands, I think you would see us want to be able to invest it within the kinds and ratios that we've talked about in the past. And as I always say to the team, here, volume's the magic elixir. It's a great category and we get really good returns on the investments we make versus our brand. But clearly, we've got to be driving volume to make that story look optimal.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say our focus is really optimization. How do we optimize and continue to be consumer centric and brand building? So not really a big change in that piece of the business model.
componenttext: Yes, I would say our focus is really optimization. How do we optimize and continue to be consumer centric and brand building? So not really a big change in that piece of the business model.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow-up on a lot of discussion about innovation on the call. And obviously, you've expressed a commitment to bringing new product to market to drive category growth. But I was wondering if you could speak to the pace of innovation in te
componenttext: I just wanted to follow-up on a lot of discussion about innovation on the call. And obviously, you've expressed a commitment to bringing new product to market to drive category growth. But I was wondering if you could speak to the pace of innovation in terms of the timing and the ability to get an idea or a product from development to shelf. It sounds like some of your competitors and some of the more, I guess, smaller niche operators have been bringing new products to market in a quicker fashion and I wonder, the extent to which you've thought about, is your pace of innovation timely enough to respond to consumer time?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, thank you for the question. I think it's more about the productivity of innovation than it is the pace of innovation. And so, when you look at things like mouth that we were very successful with and it continues to be productive for us, it's what I
componenttext: Sure, thank you for the question. I think it's more about the productivity of innovation than it is the pace of innovation. And so, when you look at things like mouth that we were very successful with and it continues to be productive for us, it's what I call a sticky innovation. It's innovation that lasts. It's many times a platform and it allows you, then, to expand even across brands because you've identified a need stay that's really important. If you look at how we classify innovation, actually our numbers versus our innovation targets are actually pretty good this year. I mean, it's not that they're wildly different, but what you have to really achieve is that stickiness and then the thing that it gets you to the platform innovation. So we have a really good pipeline of things in front of us. And so I don't think it's about all of a sudden having to start focusing against innovation. It's really making sure that we're bringing the right innovation to the market with the right investments and productivity. So that's really how I think about it. And Michele may have something she wants to add, but that's how I think about your question.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I agree. I think it's about quality and sustainability. Just making sure that we have -- we stick true to our model on that front.
componenttext: No, I agree. I think it's about quality and sustainability. Just making sure that we have -- we stick true to our model on that front.
